head.title: Black, White, Gray: America Talks About Race

hedline.hl1: Black, White, Gray: America Talks About Race

abstract.p: Cecelia Holland letter says that, as white person, she takes slight by person of color 'quietly, as a penance'

block.p: Many people seem to believe that whites don't think about prejudice and think it doesn't exist anymore (''How Race Is Lived in America''). This is not true. I think about race issues all the time. Because of my skin color, I share a weight of guilt and shame. I recognize the bias in the society, and I recognize a habitual bias in myself. Every time I see a person darker than I am, I work on this. I force myself to see and understand my biases and then to eliminate them.

Many people seem to believe that whites don't think about prejudice and think it doesn't exist anymore (''How Race Is Lived in America''). This is not true. I think about race issues all the time. Because of my skin color, I share a weight of guilt and shame. I recognize the bias in the society, and I recognize a habitual bias in myself. Every time I see a person darker than I am, I work on this. I force myself to see and understand my biases and then to eliminate them.

I am one of those white people who, when slighted by a person of color, take it quietly, as a penance. I am one of those who long for the time, which I almost certainly will not see, when we don't think constantly about race, when we're all just human beings.
